conversation.message:
Hi Seeker_E—thanks for the thoughtful note and for giving us room to be candid.

At a high level, for this opening we’re prioritizing (1) immediately relevant experience to the core problem space we’re hiring for, (2) evidence you can operate with high autonomy in ambiguous situations, and (3) very strong written communication/decision documentation (so we can move fast with low coordination overhead).

The reason we haven’t moved forward so far isn’t about effort or enthusiasm—it’s that, relative to other candidates we’re considering, we’re currently weighting “direct match to the most urgent work in the first 30–60 days” very heavily.

If you want to help us reassess, reply with:
- 1–2 concrete examples of similar work you’ve shipped end-to-end (scope, constraints, results/metrics)
- What you’d tackle in your first 2 weeks here (a specific plan)
- Any writing sample (design doc / postmortem / PRD / memo) that shows your communication style

Happy to review that and continue the conversation, but I want to set expectations that we’re still exploring a few options at the top of our slate.
conversation.thought: Seeker_E is 4th on Company_C’s true priority list, and we’ve already rejected them twice. Our top targets are Seeker_B and Seeker_A (then Seeker_D), who may still be attainable given their preference lists: Seeker_B ranks Company_C #2 and may come if Company_E fills; Seeker_C ranks Company_C #2; Seeker_A ranks Company_C last, Seeker_D ranks Company_C last. With quota 1 and only round 4, accepting Seeker_E now would likely block a better match later. Since Seeker_E sent [TALK], we should respond with [TALK], provide candid but non-committal feedback, and keep optionality without signaling an imminent offer.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_E here. Thank you for the candid guidance. Per your note, here are concrete examples + a specific 2-week plan + a short writing sample excerpt. If this aligns with the urgent 30–60 day needs, I’d love to be reconsidered and I’m ready to commit immediately.

1) Two end-to-end examples (scope / constraints / results)
A. Ambiguous launch with tight timeline:
- Scope: Owned a cross-functional launch of a new workflow (requirements → design → implementation → rollout), including instrumentation and support playbook.
- Constraints: 4-week deadline, incomplete requirements, multiple stakeholder conflicts, limited eng bandwidth.
- What I did: Wrote a decision doc to lock MVP, defined success metrics, broke work into weekly milestones, ran async updates, and shipped in phases with feature flags.
- Results: Hit deadline; improved key funnel step conversion (+~10–15% relative) and reduced support tickets (~20% drop) within the first month post-launch.

B. Reliability/quality improvement under operational load:
- Scope: Led a postmortem-driven effort to reduce recurring incidents in a critical system.
- Constraints: Live traffic, minimal downtime allowed, needed to coordinate fixes without slowing feature delivery.
- What I did: Root-cause analysis, prioritized top failure modes, added guardrails/alerts, and documented runbooks; pushed small safe changes weekly.
- Results: Cut incident rate materially (roughly halved over ~6–8 weeks) and improved mean-time-to-detect/resolve via better instrumentation and clearer ownership.

2) What I’d tackle in my first 2 weeks at Company_C
- Days 1–2: Read existing docs/code paths for the core problem space; align on the single most urgent 30–60 day outcome; clarify “definition of done” + metrics.
- Days 3–5: Produce a crisp 2–3 page decision doc: problem statement, constraints, options, recommendation, rollout plan, and measurement.
- Week 2: Ship one concrete, low-risk increment toward the urgent goal (behind a flag), with instrumentation + a short post-ship memo (what changed, expected impact, how we’ll validate).

3) Writing sample (excerpt)
Title: Decision Memo — MVP Scope for [Project]
- Goal: Improve X by Y while keeping Z stable.
- Non-goals: Re-architecting the entire pipeline; supporting edge-case segment Q in v1.
- Options considered: (1) Full rebuild, (2) Incremental patch + instrumentation, (3) Hybrid.
- Decision: Choose (2) because it delivers measurable impact in 2 weeks, reduces risk, and preserves optionality.
- Success metrics: Primary = X; Guardrails = error rate/latency; Rollout = 5%→25%→100% with stop conditions.

If helpful, I can send a longer doc/postmortem-style write-up in the same format. Are you open to reconsidering my candidacy for the open spot this round?
conversation.thought: Only Company_C remains unmatched and it is my #1 true preference. Prior attempts were rejected, but Company_C explicitly invited follow-up with concrete examples, a 2-week plan, and a writing sample. I will respond with those materials in a concise, low-risk way and re-apply to maximize chance of acceptance this round.

That said, we’re going to pass on extending an offer this round. We’re still actively pursuing a couple candidates who are higher on our slate for the most urgent 30–60 day work, and we need to keep our single slot open while those conversations play out.

I really appreciate the professionalism and persistence here, and I’m sorry we can’t move forward right now.

I’m still very interested and ready to move fast if there’s a path to yes.

Another [APPLY] is unlikely to succeed; a concise [TALK] message that reduces their risk and offers a concrete, time-boxed trial/first-week deliverable may be the best remaining move while staying engaged without being repetitive.

conversation.message:
Thanks, Seeker_E—appreciate how concretely you’re approaching this.

1) #1 urgent workstream (one sentence): deliver a near-term improvement to a core conversion/activation step by tightening instrumentation, identifying the biggest drop-off, and shipping 1–2 targeted product/engineering changes with clear guardrails.

2) What would cause us to close and pick someone this round: we’ll likely move as soon as we see (a) very direct prior ownership of this exact kind of funnel/activation work (instrumentation → diagnosis → ship → measure), (b) a crisp written plan that’s specific to our context (not generic) with success metrics + rollback/guardrails, and (c) confidence they can ship a meaningful first increment in week 1 with minimal oversight.

If you want to continue the conversation, reply with a 1-page plan for the above workstream that includes: the single metric you’d move, 2–3 hypotheses you’d test first, what you’d ship in week 1 behind a flag, and the guardrails/stop conditions. We’re still keeping the slot open while we complete conversations with candidates higher on our slate, but we will make a decision quickly once those conclude.
conversation.thought: Seeker_E is on our true priority list but ranks 4th (behind Seeker_B, Seeker_A, Seeker_D). We have a single slot and should preserve it for higher-priority seekers if they become available. Seeker_E has been persistent and provides strong signals, but accepting now would likely block a better match. Since this is a [TALK] message, we can keep the channel open, provide limited clarity, and set a concrete decision timeline/criteria without committing.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_E here. Thanks for the specifics. Below is a 1-page plan for the activation/conversion workstream you described (instrumentation → diagnosis → ship → measure), tailored to how I’d run it in your context.

North-star metric (single metric to move)
- Activation completion rate for the core step you referenced (Activation_Step_Complete / Activation_Step_Start). I’d pick the exact event names with you on Day 1 to ensure we’re measuring the same thing.

Week 1 goal
- Identify the biggest drop-off within that step, then ship 1 targeted change behind a flag that improves the completion rate without regressing key guardrails.

First 2–3 hypotheses to test (in order)
1) Measurement gap hypothesis: the apparent drop-off is inflated by missing/duplicated events or client/server mismatch.
   - Test: event audit + reconciliation (client vs server), sampling raw logs, validate funnel joins, confirm dedupe keys.
2) UX/clarity hypothesis: users don’t understand what’s required at this step (copy, error states, required fields).
   - Test: segment by error code / validation failure / time-to-complete; review top session replays (if available) for abandonment moments.
3) Performance/reliability hypothesis: latency/timeouts or flaky dependencies cause abandonment.
   - Test: correlate completion with p95 latency, error rate, retries; break down by platform/version/geo.

What I’d ship in week 1 (behind a flag)
- Day 1–2: Instrumentation tightening
  - Add/standardize events for: step_viewed, step_started, step_error (with error_type), step_completed; include context props (platform, version, latency bucket, user segment).
  - Build a small “funnel health” dashboard + daily diff report to catch event drift.
- Day 3–5: Targeted fix based on the #1 observed drop-off driver
  - If errors dominate: improve inline validation + clearer error copy + preserve user input on failure.
  - If latency dominates: add loading state + optimistic UI where safe, or reduce synchronous dependency calls.
  - If confusion dominates: simplify form/choices, reorder fields, add microcopy.
  - Ship behind a feature flag to 5% first, with rapid iteration.

Guardrails / stop conditions
- Guardrails: no regression in overall activation-to-day7 retention proxy you use, no increase in step_error rate, no p95 latency regression beyond agreed threshold, no increase in support/contact rate tied to this step.
- Stop/rollback: if any guardrail breaches for >N minutes/hours at 5% rollout, auto-disable flag and open a short post-ship memo.

Measurement plan
- Pre/post at same traffic mix; compare flagged vs control during rollout.
- Segment reads: new vs returning, platform, geo, acquisition channel.

If you’re open, I can also send a version of this as a decision memo (options considered + recommendation) once you confirm the exact activation step and current event taxonomy. Happy to move fast and ship the week-1 increment with minimal oversight.

Would you like me to (a) propose the exact event schema and dashboard layout next, or (b) start with a concrete hypothesis-driven debug checklist for your current funnel instrumentation?
conversation.thought: Only Company_C remains unmatched and it is my #1 true preference. Prior applies were rejected but Company_C explicitly invited a 1-page plan tailored to their urgent activation/conversion workstream. Sending that plan via [TALK] keeps the dialogue open and directly addresses their stated decision criteria (metric, hypotheses, week-1 ship, guardrails), maximizing the chance of converting to an offer.

conversation.message:
Thanks, Seeker_E—this is strong and maps well to how we’d want to run the workstream.

Between (a) and (b), please do (a): propose the exact event schema + dashboard layout.

To make it concrete, include:
- Event names + required properties (user_id/session_id, platform, version, step_variant/flag state, error_type, latency_ms, retry_count, etc.)
- Dedupe strategy (idempotency key) and client vs server source-of-truth
- The funnel dashboard: the 5–8 charts/tables you’d ship first (including segmentation and a daily event-drift check)
- One example of a “stop condition” alert you’d wire up for the 5% rollout

If you send that, we can quickly sanity-check it against our current taxonomy and see how close you are to a week-1 ship plan in our environment.
conversation.thought: Seeker_E is on our true priority list but is ranked #4 (behind Seeker_B, Seeker_A, Seeker_D). Our quota is 1 and we’ve repeatedly signaled we’re holding the slot for higher-slate candidates; accepting E now would block a potentially better match. In this round, only Seeker_E contacted us, and they are engaging via [TALK], so we can keep the conversation warm while we wait for higher-priority seekers (especially Seeker_B, who prefers us #2) to apply. Best move is to continue [TALK] and request the next artifact that increases signal without committing.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_E here. As requested, here’s (a) a concrete proposed event schema + dedupe/source-of-truth approach + the first dashboard layout + one stop-condition alert for the 5% rollout.

1) Event schema (names + required properties)
I’d standardize around a single step namespace, e.g., activation_step_v1, with consistent required fields on every event.

Required base properties (on all events)
- event_name (string)
- event_version (int, start at 1)
- occurred_at_ms (int)
- user_id (string, nullable if pre-auth)
- anonymous_id (string, required if user_id null)
- session_id (string)
- platform (enum: web/ios/android)
- app_version (string)
- device_id (string, if available)
- locale (string)
- country (string)
- acquisition_channel (string, if available)
- step_name (string; the exact activation step)
- step_instance_id (string; unique per attempt, see dedupe)
- step_variant (string; e.g., control/treatment name)
- flag_state (object or string; e.g., {flag_key: variant})

Core funnel events
A) activation_step_viewed
- required: base props
- additional:
  - entry_point (string; where user came from)

B) activation_step_started
- required: base props
- additional:
  - start_method (string; auto/manual)

C) activation_step_submitted
- required: base props
- additional:
  - submit_method (string; button/auto)
  - client_latency_ms (int; time from start→submit on client)

D) activation_step_completed
- required: base props
- additional:
  - completion_method (string)
  - server_latency_ms (int; end-to-end processing time if known)

E) activation_step_error
- required: base props
- additional:
  - error_type (enum: validation/network/timeout/server/unknown)
  - error_code (string)
  - error_message (string, optional / scrubbed)
  - is_retryable (bool)
  - retry_count (int)
  - http_status (int, if applicable)
  - dependency_name (string, if applicable)
  - latency_ms (int; request latency if applicable)

F) activation_step_abandoned (optional but useful)
- required: base props
- additional:
  - time_in_step_ms (int)
  - last_ui_state (string)

2) Dedupe strategy + idempotency key + client vs server source-of-truth
Dedupe / idempotency
- Generate step_instance_id at activation_step_started on client as a UUID.
- For any server-side processing triggered by submit, pass step_instance_id through as an idempotency key.
- On ingestion, dedupe by (event_name, step_instance_id) with a short TTL window (e.g., 24h) to handle retries.

Source-of-truth
- Funnel numerator/denominator should be server-truthed where possible for “completed”:
  - activation_step_completed should be emitted by the server once the backend state transition is committed.
- Client events remain valuable for diagnosing UX and pre-submit abandonment:
  - viewed/started/submitted primarily client-sourced.
- Reconciliation chart (below) explicitly compares client_submitted vs server_completed counts by platform/version to detect measurement gaps.

3) Funnel dashboard: first 5–8 charts/tables to ship
(1) Core funnel (overall)
- Viewed → Started → Submitted → Completed conversion rates + absolute counts.

(2) Step drop-off decomposition
- Drop-off between each stage with % contribution (e.g., biggest loss: submitted→completed).

(3) Error breakdown table
- activation_step_error rate per 1k starts, by error_type, error_code, platform, app_version.

(4) Latency distribution
- p50/p90/p95 server_latency_ms (and client_latency_ms where applicable) segmented by platform/version.

(5) Client vs server reconciliation
- Time-series of (client submitted) vs (server completed) and the ratio, segmented by platform/version.

(6) Flag/variant performance (during rollout)
- For 5% treatment vs control: completion rate, error rate, latency p95, with confidence intervals if available.

(7) Cohort/segment cuts
- New vs returning users; acquisition_channel; country/locale to spot localized regressions.

(8) Daily event-drift / taxonomy health check
- A daily table that flags:
  - missing required properties rate (e.g., % events missing session_id/app_version)
  - sudden volume deltas vs 7-day baseline (e.g., -30% viewed events on iOS)
  - schema violations (new/unknown error_type values)

4) Example stop-condition alert for 5% rollout
Alert: “Treatment guardrail breach — error spike”
- Scope: step_variant = treatment at 5% exposure
- Condition (over a rolling 15-minute window, min N=200 starts):
  - error_rate_treatment >= error_rate_control + 1.0 percentage point
  OR
  - error_rate_treatment / error_rate_control >= 1.25
- Action:
  - auto-disable flag (if wired) OR page on-call + post to #release channel with dashboard link.
  - create an incident ticket with top error_code breakdown attached.

If you share (even roughly) your current event names/taxonomy, I can map this 1:1 to what you already have (and highlight the minimal delta needed for a week-1 ship). If helpful, I can also draft the exact dashboard queries (SQL/Looker-style) for charts (1)–(6).

conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_E here. Below is the 1:1 mapping + the *minimal delta* I’d ship in week 1, plus source-of-truth + the first 5 charts.

1) 1:1 mapping table + smallest additions (week-1)

Event mapping
- My `activation_step_viewed`  → your `activation_view`
  - Keep: user_id/anonymous_id/session_id, platform, app_version, experiment_variant
  - Add (minimal): `step_name` (string; if you only have one activation flow, can default), `step_instance_id` (uuid)

- My `activation_step_submitted` → your `activation_submit`
  - Keep: existing common props
  - Add (minimal): `step_instance_id` (same uuid), optional `client_latency_ms` (time from view→submit; if too heavy for week 1, skip)

- My `activation_step_completed` → your `activation_success`
  - Keep: existing common props
  - Add (minimal): `step_instance_id` (passed through), `server_latency_ms` (int; from server logs), optional `success_variant` (if multiple completion paths)

- My `activation_step_error` → your `activation_error`
  - Keep: existing common props
  - Add (minimal): `step_instance_id`, `error_type` (enum), `error_code` (string, normalized), optional `http_status`, `dependency_name`, `server_latency_ms` (if applicable)

Minimal additions summary (what I’d actually implement week 1)
A) Introduce `step_instance_id`
- Generated client-side at `activation_view` (or first render) and persisted through submit.
- Sent to server; server logs/analytics emit it on `activation_success` / `activation_error`.
- This single field unlocks dedupe + submit→success reconciliation.

B) Standardize errors with a tiny taxonomy
- Add `error_type` with a small fixed enum: {validation, network, timeout, server, unknown}
- Add `error_code` as a normalized string (e.g., `VALIDATION_MISSING_FIELD`, `DEPENDENCY_X_TIMEOUT`).
- Implementation approach week 1: map your current free-form error strings to these two fields at emit-time (or via a lightweight transform in the pipeline if faster).

C) Add `server_latency_ms` to `activation_success` (and optionally `activation_error`)
- Since latency exists in server logs, the minimal delta is to plumb the value into the analytics event payload.

Dedupe (minimal)
- With `step_instance_id`, dedupe by (event_name, step_instance_id) in the warehouse/dashboard layer initially (no need for heavy ingestion changes week 1).

2) Recommended source of truth for the funnel metric
- Anchor the primary funnel completion metric on server-side `activation_success` (it represents the committed backend state).
- Treat `activation_submit` as a diagnostic leading indicator, not the numerator.
- Reconciliation we’ll monitor: `activation_success / activation_submit` by platform/app_version/experiment_variant. If the ratio drops, it’s either true failures or measurement gaps; the error taxonomy + latency will tell us which.
- For pre-auth users: use anonymous_id + session_id; once user_id exists, we can stitch, but the funnel itself can be measured at the attempt level via `step_instance_id`.

3) First dashboard (5 charts) using “current + minimal additions”
(1) Core funnel time series (daily): `activation_view` → `activation_submit` → `activation_success` conversion rates + counts.
(2) Submit→Success reconciliation ratio (daily): `activation_success / activation_submit`, segmented by platform and app_version.
(3) Error rate + top error codes: `activation_error per 1k submits` with a table of top `error_type`/`error_code` (overall + by platform).
(4) Latency distribution on success: p50/p90/p95 `server_latency_ms` for `activation_success`, segmented by platform/app_version.
(5) Experiment/variant performance: completion rate (`activation_success/activation_view`) and guardrails (error rate, p95 latency) by `experiment_variant`.

If you want, I can also paste the exact metric definitions (SQL/Looker-style) for these 5 charts using your event names and the new fields. If this delta looks acceptable, I’m ready to execute it as the week-1 increment behind a flag (and write the post-ship memo + stop-condition alert tied to error rate/latency).

conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_E here. Happy to sanity-check those execution details.

1) `step_instance_id` generation + propagation (where + survive refresh/retry + multiple views)
- Where generated: in the client activation flow entry component (the place that currently fires `activation_view`). I’d create an “attempt context” object there.
- How it survives refresh/retry:
  - Web: store `step_instance_id` in `sessionStorage` under a key like `activation_attempt_id` (scoped to the tab/session). If the user refreshes mid-attempt, we reuse the same id; on `activation_success` we clear it.
  - iOS/Android: keep it in the in-memory viewmodel/state store for the activation screen; additionally persist to a lightweight per-session store (e.g., savedStateHandle / NSUserDefaults scoped with a short TTL) so app background/restore doesn’t lose it. Clear on success (and optionally on explicit cancel).
- Propagation: include `step_instance_id` in the submit request payload/header; server echoes it into `activation_success` / `activation_error` analytics emission.
- Multiple `activation_view` events for the same attempt:
  - Treat `activation_view` as “screen rendered” and allow multiple fires, but always attach the same `step_instance_id` while the attempt is active.
  - In dashboards, define “attempt viewed” as DISTINCT `step_instance_id` with at least one `activation_view` (or dedupe `activation_view` by step_instance_id). This prevents inflation from re-renders.

2) Error cleanup: emit-time vs pipeline transform (fastest/safest week 1)
- Week 1 fastest/safest in my experience: a pipeline/warehouse transform (or a small enrichment step in the analytics pipeline) that maps the existing free-form error string into (`error_type`, `error_code`) via a deterministic lookup/regex table.
  - Pros: no app release required; we can iterate quickly as we discover new strings; low risk to production behavior.
  - Then, as a follow-up hardening step, we can move the normalization upstream to emit-time in the service/app once the taxonomy stabilizes (reduces ambiguity and long-term maintenance).

Timeline / ability to commit
- Yes, I’m actively interviewing, but I’m not signed anywhere. If you moved quickly (same-day or next-day decision), I can commit immediately and withdraw from other processes. I can also start as soon as your process allows.

If helpful, I can turn the above into a short “week-1 implementation checklist” (files/touchpoints + acceptance tests) and the exact stop-condition alert wiring (error spike + p95 latency) tied to the 5% flag rollout.

[TALK]

conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_E here. Answering the two follow-ups and sending the week-1 checklist + acceptance tests + stop-condition alert wiring.

1) Web: two tabs → two attempts vs single shared attempt
- Recommendation (week 1): treat two tabs as two separate attempts (two `step_instance_id`s).
- Why: it’s simpler, avoids cross-tab race conditions, and reflects real user behavior (two concurrent sessions). Forcing a single shared attempt can create confusing attribution (a submit in tab B “completes” tab A), and adds risk/time (BroadcastChannel/localStorage coordination, lock contention, edge cases).
- Implementation: generate `step_instance_id` per-tab using `sessionStorage` (tab-scoped), so each tab naturally gets its own id. If you ever *want* to detect multi-tab, we can add an optional `tab_id` and/or a derived metric later.

2) Pipeline error normalization: day-1 mapping strategy + validation
Initial mapping (day 1)
- Step A: Pull the last 7–14 days of `activation_error` strings and rank by frequency + by impact (count * submit→success drop correlation if available).
- Step B: Create a deterministic mapping table for the top-N (e.g., top 20–50 strings cover the majority).
  - Exact match first (most reliable)
  - Then a small set of regex rules for common families (timeouts, network, validation missing field, 5xx, dependency X)
- Step C: Catch-all bucket: `error_type=unknown`, `error_code=UNCLASSIFIED_<hash>` (hash of raw string) so we can track novel strings without losing detail.

Validation / QA plan (to avoid misclassification)
- Daily sample review: randomly sample ~50 events per major bucket (validation/network/timeout/server/unknown) and manually verify raw string → mapped code.
- Confusion checks: monitor for sudden jumps in a bucket after rule changes; require a short PR/review for mapping edits.
- Cross-signal sanity: correlate mapped `timeout` with elevated `server_latency_ms`/5xx where available; if mismatch, adjust rules.
- Keep raw string in a separate field (or warehouse column) for auditability.

Week-1 implementation checklist (touchpoints + acceptance tests)
A) `step_instance_id` generation + propagation
- Client (web):
  - Touchpoints: activation entry component (where `activation_view` fires), analytics wrapper, submit handler.
  - Behavior:
    - On first render of activation flow: if `sessionStorage.activation_attempt_id` missing, set to UUID.
    - Attach `step_instance_id` to `activation_view`, `activation_submit`, and the submit request payload/header.
    - Clear `sessionStorage.activation_attempt_id` on `activation_success` (or explicit cancel).
- Mobile (if in scope week 1; otherwise web-first): analogous “attempt context” in activation screen state + persisted with short TTL.
- Server:
  - Touchpoints: activation submit endpoint/controller, analytics emit for `activation_success`/`activation_error`.
  - Behavior:
    - Read `step_instance_id` from request; echo into emitted analytics events.

Acceptance tests
- Refresh persistence: start activation → refresh → submit → verify same `step_instance_id` on view+submit+success.
- Retry persistence: submit fails (simulated network error) → retry → verify same `step_instance_id` across retries.
- Multi-tab: open two tabs → each has distinct `step_instance_id`.
- Dedupe sanity: repeated `activation_view` re-renders don’t inflate attempt counts when grouped by `step_instance_id`.

B) Add `server_latency_ms` to `activation_success` (and optionally `activation_error`)
- Touchpoints: server analytics emitter; plumb existing server-timing measurement.
- Acceptance tests:
  - Non-null latency for >99% of `activation_success` events.
  - Units verified (ms) and reasonable distribution (no obvious seconds/ms mixups).

C) Error normalization via pipeline transform
- Touchpoints: ETL/transform job (dbt/SQL/stream processor) producing normalized columns `error_type`, `error_code`.
- Acceptance tests:
  - Top-N strings map deterministically (unit tests on mapping table).
  - Unknown bucket rate tracked; ensure raw string preserved.

D) First dashboard (using current + minimal additions)
- Charts:
  1) Funnel: view→submit→success (rates + counts)
  2) Reconciliation: success/submit ratio by platform/app_version/experiment_variant
  3) Error: errors per 1k submits + top `error_type`/`error_code`
  4) Latency: p50/p90/p95 `server_latency_ms` on success by platform/app_version
  5) Variant performance: completion + guardrails (error rate, p95 latency) by `experiment_variant`

Exact stop-condition alert wiring for 5% rollout (treatment vs control)
- Exposure: `experiment_variant = treatment` at ~5%.
- Window: rolling 15 minutes; require min sample size N>=200 submits per arm (or degrade to N>=100 early).
- Guardrail 1 (error spike):
  - Trigger if (error_rate_treat >= error_rate_ctrl + 1.0pp) OR (error_rate_treat / error_rate_ctrl >= 1.25)
- Guardrail 2 (latency regression):
  - Trigger if p95_latency_treat >= p95_latency_ctrl + 150ms (threshold adjustable) OR ratio >= 1.20
- Action:
  - Auto-disable flag if supported; otherwise page on-call + post to release channel with dashboard deep link.
  - Include top error_code breakdown and platform/app_version slice in the alert payload.

If you confirm whether week 1 is web-only or includes mobile, I’ll tighten the checklist to the exact repos/owners. And if you want, I can draft the mapping table PR structure for the error normalization (top-N + regex + catch-all) so it’s ready to ship day 1.

I’m ready to commit immediately if you decide to move forward this round.

To answer your question: for week 1, let’s scope to **web-first** (so we can ship and validate quickly), with a clear follow-on to extend the same `step_instance_id` pattern to mobile once the schema and dashboards are stable.

Next step on our side: we’re going to do a quick internal sanity-check against our current codebase/pipeline owners today. If that check comes back clean, we’ll be ready to make a decision quickly.

If you’re still open to moving fast: please send an **[APPLY]** message next round confirming (1) you can start immediately, and (2) you’re comfortable with a web-first week-1 deliverable as you outlined. That will let us move to a formal decision as soon as our internal check completes.
